title-group.article-title: Should Central Government Seek to Control the Level of Local Authority Expenditures?

abstract.p: Should local authorities be free to determine their expenditure, provided they finance changes in spending by changes in local taxation? We set up a theoretical framework to analyse this issue, and discuss three arguments that have been put forward for central control of such spending. The first relates to tax spillovers, the second to distributional effects combined with imperfect local democracy and the third considers self-interested local politicians. While these arguments cannot be entirely dismissed, they are subject to numerous qualifications and, if correct, would imply the desirability of a number of policies other than expenditure capping.

p.mixed-citation: More strictly, the debate concerns control of what, in the UK, is called local authority self-financed expenditure (LASFE).
For an account of how capping has operated in the UK, and an attempt to assess its economic consequences, see, for example, Emmerson, Hall and Windmeijer (1998).
See, for example, the Treasury's evidence to the House of Lords Select Committee on Relations between Central and Local Government (House of Lords, 1996, vol. II, pp. 280-3 and 308-9).
However, see Bailey (1999, ch. 5) and Jackson (1999).

0ur tax variables should be interpreted as representing net tax receipts — that is, total tax revenue less transfer payments. Sometimes the spillover effects we discuss have their impact by affecting transfer payments.

We hence ignore questions of strategic interaction, which have featured in some of the recent theoretical literature (for example, Figuieres, Hindriks and Myles (2001)). Such questions may be important in considering issues relating to fiscal federalism in the European Union, but we consider our approach more relevant for the analysis of UK local authorities.
Such a condition is fairly standard in the literature (see, for example, equation (3) on p. 288 of Case, Hines and Rosen (1993)).

These are sufficient conditions — the failure of any one of these conditions to hold does not necessarily mean that there is a case for CG control of LA expenditure. (It might be possible, for example, for LAs to agree amongst themselves in a Coasian fashion on measures to internalise external effects without necessarily involving the CG.)
The implications of this scheme are discussed at greater length in Watt and Fender (1999).
These are not unreasonable figures to use for the distortionary costs of taxation. For further discussion of estimates of these costs, see Ruggeri (1999).

A complication comes from the fact that £15 (of the £31 increase in spending) is considered 'one-off expenditure. If we are considering a permanent increase in LA spending, then we would need to convert this into its annual flow equivalent which, assuming a 10 per cent interest rate, would be £1.50. This means that a permanent annual increase of £100 in LA spending would raise the CG fiscal deficit by £37.50 annually, implying the appropriate rate of withdrawal of government grant per £100 increase in LA spending is just £3.75.

As already noted, much of the extensive recent theoretical literature on local public finance assumes a high or (sometimes) an infinite degree of mobility of the local tax base. We would point out that many of the contributors to this literature come from countries (such as the US and Germany) with very different systems of local taxation, for which an assumption of a high degree of interregional mobility of the tax base is much more relevant.

0ur companion paper, Watt and Fender (1999), contains some discussion of the actual arrangements whereby LA capital spending is controlled in the UK, and the government has recently proposed some major changes (see Department for Transport, Local Government and the Regions (2001b)); here, we are more concerned with the theoretical arguments.

However, it might be argued that if local revenue is raised by a property tax, then expected future increases in local taxes will be capitalised into property prices, so eliminating the 'mismatch' problem: local taxpayers cannot shift the cost of local services onto future local residents since the higher future taxes mean lower current property prices.

For this reason, it is entirely appropriate that LAs should not be able to control business rates (so the current system whereby the business rate is set centrally is welcome), since the incidence of such rates probably falls largely on those outside the LA area. At the moment, although LAs finance only a fraction of their spending by taxation that they control (about a quarter — see Table 2), it is true to say that at the margin, subject to the qualification made earlier about council tax benefit, they pay the full cost of any increase in their spending themselves. We believe it would be desirable for LAs to finance a much greater proportion of their expenditures by taxes that they control, but discussion of this is beyond the scope of this paper. (For one of the author's ideas on how this might be done, see Fender (1986).)

We would also point out that if, in spite of our arguments, it is decided that the level of LA spending should be controlled for this particular reason, there is no need to control each individual LA's spending; it is only necessary to control the aggregate. A way of doing the latter whilst preserving individual LAs' freedom to set their own levels of expenditure would be to issue LAs with marketable permits, enabling them to increase their spending above their Standard Spending Assessments (SSAs). So if one LA wanted to raise its expenditure by a certain amount above its SSA, and did not have enough permits, it would have to buy such permits from other LAs, which would thus need to reduce their expenditure. The market for such permits would work in a similar way to the recently established market in sulphur dioxide emissions allowances in the US. (This argument also holds if CG seeks to control LA spending for macroeconomic reasons.)
